data.name: St. Moritz Skating Club
data.abstract: Members of the skating club take to the ice to train with skating instructor Valentina.
data.description: The 1928 and 1948 Winter Olympics were held on the natural ice rink in front of the Kulm Country Club. This is the spot where freshly sharpened skate blades cut the untouched ice. Led by figure skater Valentina Perisco, the course will show women how to make a stylish impression on the ice. The club offers everyone a clear learning path, and beginners and elite athletes practise side-by-side, each according to their level. Learn to skate forwards and backwards, stopping, gliding, switching, and turning. In the elite training, advanced skaters will practise jumps and pirouettes and hone their competition programs.

data.name: St. Moritz - First ski experience
data.abstract: Learn to ski in the place where the world's top ski athletes compete: on Corviglia above St. Moritz. Your first ski lesson is rewarded with a carriage ride to the slope and back.
data.description:
Learner skiers on St. Moritz's local mountain Corviglia practise their sport on the mountain that has probably seen the most prizes won in wintersport history: Two Winter Olympics plus five FIS Alpine Ski World Championships have already been held here. Ski equipment including hired clothing is provided by Ski Service Engadin St. Moritz. 

Optimally equipped, you'll then take the funicular railway from St. Moritz village up to the middle station. A carriage awaits novice skiers at Chantarella to take them to the teaching ground of the St. Moritz ski school. Under the ski instructor's expert guidance, beginners will be carving their first curves in the snow in no time. After the lesson there's another stylish journey by carriage back to the tradition-steeped funicular railway.

Package price including 2 hours of private tuition, skis and ski boots, transport by horse-drawn carriage and the funicular railway from St Moritz village up to the middle station.

data.name: Engadine St. Moritz – Switzerland’s cross-country paradise
data.abstract: St. Moritz was birthplace of alpine winter sports (1864) and venue of two Olympic Winter Games. The Swiss paradise with golden tracks offers all kinds of spectacular cross-country pleasures: diverse unique landscapes, top of the range trails and your best bet for snow!
data.description:
Those who prefer to take things easy select the Direttissima over three lakes, or glide over the longest trail of its sort in Zuoz, Engadine. The ambitious train on the legendary marathon stretch, Switzerland’s most famous 42 kilometers, conquer the picturesque side valleys or test their skills on the racing stretch in St. Moritz, where they can also extend activity until late at night on the night trail. 

On the occasion of the biggest sport event, namely the Engadine Ski Marathon, Engadine couldn’t stand up to its title as cross-country Mecca any better! Now’s the time to watch around 13,000 cross-country fans take to their skis in an attempt to be the first to cover the 42 kilometer distance from Maloja via St. Moritz to S-chanf. 
Altitude: 1450 to 2200 meters above sea level 
Classic trail: 240km 
Skating: 245km 
Night trail: 3.5km 
Dog trail: 7.5km

data.name: Photo Spot Engadine St. Moritz
data.abstract: St. Moritz ranks amongst the world’s top holiday destinations. Steeped in tradition, it is the birthplace of winter tourism in the Alps (1864) and the venue of two Winter Olympic Games. St. Moritz came to prominence through its hot springs, which have been known for 3,000 years and have long helped establish the village as a summer spa. World-class leisure, culture, shopping, events, hospitality and gastronomy: the name St. Moritz promises – and delivers – much.

data.name: Olympic bob run in St. Moritz-Celerina
data.abstract: The Olympic Bob Run St. Moritz-Celerina is the world's only natural ice bob run and also the oldest bob run still in operation.
data.description:
Apart from the annual national and international bob championships, the run also hosts skeleton and toboggan championships at national and occasionally even at international level. In addition the "Hornschlitten" (traditioanl toboggan) race on the bob run and the Bobrun Skating event at which approximately 100 ice hockey players race down the bob run first individually and later in groups of three, constitute an integral part of the seasons program.
Opening hours are from the end of December until beginning of March, approx. 09.30 am to 12.30 noon, daily.

Location:
Starting point is behind Hotel Bären. A 10-minute walk, approx., from the village center. By Bus No. 2 to the stop "St. Moritz Bären"

Contact:

data.name: Graubünden Paragliding
data.abstract: Flims/Laax, Davos, St.Moritz, Viamala, Lenzerheide, Klosters
data.description:
Unforgettable flights amid the breathtaking mountain landscape are available from all launch points. Ascend wonderful thermals for unique cross-country flights, particularly from April to the end of September, for example from Flims [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/flims/]. But passengers and licensed pilots can also have an excellent time in Davos [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/davos/]or St.Moritz [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/st-moritz/].

data.name: Ride the Olympic Bob Run
data.abstract: A passenger ride on the St. Moritz-Celerina bob run is a 75-second rush of pure adrenaline.
data.description: As you thunder down the world's only natural ice bob run in a four-man sled with a pilot and brakeman, you'll be put to the test at the legendary "Horse Shoe" corner - if not before - and awarded a certificate at the end. This thrilling 130 km/h experience is open to anyone with a thirst for adventure and a healthy heart. Weather permitting, passenger rides are available almost every day during the winter season.

data.name: Dine on the move
data.abstract: Travelling in style. The trip from Zermatt to St. Moritz/Davos on the Glacier Express is a treat for all the senses as is a gourmet ride on the Golden- Pass Line from the Bernese Oberland to Lucerne. These panoramic routes are among the finest railway experiences to be had anywhere in the world – thanks to the breathtaking views, and to the gastronomic delights served in the dining car. Pure pleasure, in a stunning setting.
data.description:
GOLDENPASS CLASSIC
The dining car is shaped like a wine barrel. Glass in hand, you’ll glide past the most beautiful parts of Switzerland, from Zweisimmen to Montreux, pampered by the chefs and indulged by the scenery. More Information... [http://www.mob.ch] 

THE SALON BLEU ON WHEELS
The Belle Époque comes to life in this dining car in the legendary style of the Orient Express. Enjoy anything from a glass of champagne to a multi-course menu. Also available for private events. More Information... [http://www.railaway.ch/Deutsch/Extrazug/extrazug_salonBleu.html ] 

FONDUE UP ON THE MOUNTAIN, OR DOWN ON THE LAKE
Fondue is always great fun – even more so when the setting is special. You can enjoy one on Mount Rigi [http://www.rigi.ch], the panoramic mountain high above Lake Lucerne, as you travel on the vintage electric cog wheel railway dating from 1911; or on one of the much-loved fondue cruises [http://www.railaway.ch/Deutsch/Publikumsfahrten/bodenseefahrten.html] on Lake Constance. 

A TASTY TRIP THROUGH GRAUBÜNDEN
Fresh, seasonal cuisine, great wines and fine brandies are all served in the Gourmino, the nostalgic 1930s dining car that travels the network of the Rhaetian Railways. A year-round calendar offers travellers treats ranging from just-picked asparagus to Buurametzgeta (farmhouse meal featuring a variety of cured meats) and seasonal game dishes. More Information... [http://www.rhb.ch]
BREAKFAST WITH BOND – AND OTHER PEAK PLEASURES
Scaling the mighty peaks of the Alps gives you quite an appetite – even when you make the ascent in a cable car or funicular. Thankfully, when you get to the top, there are special treats in store, like the James Bond Breakfast (daily until 11am) at the Piz Gloria revolving restaurant on the Schilthorn [http://www.schilthorn.ch], where “On Her Majesty’s Secret Service” was filmed; or creamy Älplermakkaroni (alpine macaroni and cheese) on the Stanserhorn [http://www.stanserhorn.ch]; or a stylish dinner on the Brienzer Rothorn [http://www.brienz-rothorn-bahn.ch] after a spectacular ride on Switzerland’s oldest steam-powered cog railway.

data.name: Inspirational art
data.abstract: Famous artists have found inspiration here, while some lesser-known lights have taken their work to new heights. So a walk through the galleries and museums of St. Moritz is a great way to see familiar sights through fresh eyes.
data.description:
The Segantini Museum is a traditional favourite, while the Mili Weber Haus is one of a kind. Amazing spaces such as Galerie Gmurzynska and the Vito Schnabel Gallery draw visitors into a uniquely inspirational world. The region has a total of 63 galleries and 23 museums. In winter, there is a buzz around the NOMAD art event, while the attraction in summer is the St. Moritz Art Masters.

Great art in small spaces [https://www.engadin.stmoritz.ch/sommer/de/museen/type.gallerie/#/city.stmoritz/type.museum,gallerie/]

data.name: By foot to Heidi’s mountain hut
data.abstract: The adventures of Heidi, the orphan girl, are known the world over. Not least through the eponymous film from 1952. One of the original locations is above St. Moritz and can be visited at all times.
data.description:
Heidi. We owe it to the Zürich author Johanna Spyri that the name became synonymous with a down-to-earth Swiss girl. It was 140 years ago that the parson’s daughter from Zürich wrote the adventures of the cheerful orphan girl. Today the work is one of the world’s most popular children’s books. 

That Heide became so widely known is also due to the marvelous film from 1952. The legendary Heinrich Gretler as Alpöhi (Alpine grandfather) remains unforgettable. If you want to visit his cabin, travel to St. Moritz and hike from there to the Salastrains area. At the end of your hike you can sit on the small wooden bench in front of the hut. Or lower your head and glance into the dark interior of the simple wooden house.

data.name: Olympia Piste
data.abstract: Even today, the Olympia Piste reminds one of the 1948 Olympic Winter Games in St. Moritz. Back then the Corviglia Chantarella downhill run placed extreme demands on skiers. Connoisseurs still regard the original route as an insider tip.
data.description:
When St. Moritz hosted the 1948 Winter Olympics the Alpine races were held on Corviglia. The men's downhill to Chantarella was regarded as being particularly difficult. Today's Olympic piste follows the original route to a large extent. Because the ski area has grown significantly since then, it is now located more on the edge. This has the advantage that it is much less crowded than the other slopes and skillful skiers can therefore take their swing turns without being disturbed. INFORMATION

Starting point: Corviglia (2486 m a.s.l.) 

Accessibility of starting point: chairlift 

Destination: Chantarella (2005 m a.s.l.) 

Altitude difference: 481 Meter 

Level of difficulty: difficult (normal slope) 

Food and beverages: at the start

data.name: Experience the delightful Engadin
data.abstract: Discover the mountain world on foot, relax in a spa and indulge in culinary delights: St. Moritz is a treat for all the senses.
data.description: Breathtaking views of the valley, benches on which to relax, idyllic lakes and clear mountain air that energises the body and mind. The easy, three-hour hike from Corvatsch via Hahnensee to St. Moritz is ideal for connoisseurs. Back in St. Moritz, you can relax your legs in the spacious Ovavera spa and sports centre and treat yourself to a massage, before indulging in some culinary delights in Japanese restaurant Kura or Thai restaurant Siam Wind.

data.name: Ovaverva Indoor Pool, Spa & Sports Centre
data.abstract: Guests at the Ovaverva Indoor Pool, Spa & Sports Centre in St. Moritz can choose from a wide range of services.
data.description:
The infrastructure includes various pools, a wellness area, a fitness centre, an outdoor sports centre, and the Ovaverva restaurant, which is open to the general public as well as spa guests. 

The name Ovaverva is derived from Romansch and its meaning is along the lines of “living, bubbling water”.

Getting there: By bus from St. Moritz train station to “St. Moritz Bad, Hallenbad” or by car (there is a public car park available).

data.name: Alp Grüm
data.abstract: Alp Grüm is a station on the Bernina line of the Rhaetian Railway and offers a unique view of the Val Poschiavo and the Palü Glacier. Its car-free, remote location makes it a popular destination for hikers, rail travelers and nature lovers.
data.description:
Alp Grüm lies at an altitude of 2,091 m and can only be reached by Rhaetian Railway or on foot. The Bernina Railway, part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site, connects St. Moritz with Tirano and stops here for an impressive panoramic view. Hiking trails lead from Ospizio Bernina or Cavaglia to the station.

The region around Alp Grüm is characterized by a high alpine landscape with views of the Palü glacier and the Val Poschiavo. Hikers appreciate the path to Lago Palü or the route into the valley. The Alp Grüm restaurant serves regional specialties and a sun terrace with far-reaching views.

data.name: Schellen Ursli Path (A Bell for Ursli Path)
data.abstract: Schellen Ursli Path - a fairy tale hike.
data.description:
For people of all ages: the Schellen Ursli Path (Via Uorsin) takes you from the Via Tinus in St. Moritz to the Heidi lodge and from there on to Salastrains in about 30 minutes. Along the way, several notices with pictures tell the story of the Engadine boy with the cowbell.

How to get there:
Take the funicular from St. Moritz-Dorf (Village) to Chantarella. From there it's a 15-minute walk to Hotel Salastrains.

data.name: Glacier Express
data.abstract: The journey in what has been dubbed the world’s slowest express train takes travellers across the Alps within roughly eight hours, passing through 91 tunnels and over 291 bridges.
data.description:
The Glacier Express offers a journey for the senses – from Engadine right to the Matterhorn. On its relaxing drive from dazzling St. Moritz to equally sophisticated Zermatt, the Glacier Express delights travellers with scenic attractions and technical state-of-the-art achievements. With its overhight panoramic windows, the Glacier Express opens up unobstructed views of unique landscapes.

Excellence Class

A rail journey through the Swiss Alps has never been so luxurious. With guaranteed window seats, an exclusive bar, on-board entertainment, a concierge service and personal travel guides, the Glacier Express Excellence Class is setting new standards. The journey between St. Moritz and Zermatt is a feast for the senses: while the spectacular landscape passes by outside, guests are served champagne and amuse-bouches – followed by an exquisite five-course meal with accompanying wine.

With this new service, the Glacier Express offers one of the most exclusive rolling touristic highlights in Switzerland. Reservations for the most sought-after seats in Switzerland can be booked at glacierexpress.ch [https://www.glacierexpress.ch/en/offers/excellence-class/].

FACTS GLACIER EXPRESS
Route: Zermatt – St. Moritz or vice versa Distance: 291 km Duration: 8 h 03 min Infotainment: Touristic announcements and infotainment system in various languages 

EXCURSION TIPS
 * Matterhorn Glacier Paradise – a view of French, Italian and Swiss mountain giants from a vantage point of almost 4000 m
 * Gornergrat – a view onto the Matterhorn and 28 other four-thousand-meter-peaks from a vantage point of 3131 m
 * Rhine Gorge – Exploring the «Grand Canyon» of Switzerland between Ilanz and Reichenau on foot, by bike or by rafting boat
 * Lake Sils – at 1800 m, Europe’s highest altitude regular scheduled passenger boat service
 * Corvatsch – the eastern Alpine region’s highest altitude summit station at 3303 m. A paradise for skiers and hikers

FOOD & BEVERAGES
 * 1st and 2nd class: lunch served at the seat – three-course meal, daily menu, or à la carte options
 * Excellence Class: Champagne and aperitif platter, 5-course-menu with wine accompaniment, soft drinks, mineral water and coffee included

TIMETABLE
Summer and winter timetable panoramic trains [https://www.glacierexpress.ch/en/timetable]

TICKET
 This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travel card.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

RESERVATION
 Apart from a valid ticket, a seat reservation is required. In addition, the train is subject to surcharge depending on the route.
Please note: The Excellence Class has a surcharge of CHF 540 on a 1st class ticket.

 Reserve here [https://shop.glacierexpress.ch/gex_en]

No dogs are permitted onboard the Glacier Express and only one piece of luggage is allowed per person.

BROCHURE
Fascinating and comprehensive information around the Glacier Express, featuring highlights and relevant facts and figures, can be downloaded here:
PDF brochure [https://www.mystsnet.com/?wpdmdl=16684&ind=1710344174761]

data.name: Mountain dining at Muottas Muragl
data.abstract: The historic funicular railway takes you up to the top station at 2453 m above sea level, where you can enjoy an unforgettable view of the magnificent snow-covered, indescribably vast valley. While the last rays of the sun bathe the Engadin in a golden glow, you will be served traditional dishes of the region. At about 11 p.m., the last cable-car will take you back down to the sea of lights that is the village.
data.description:
Enjoy:  * a ride on the oldest cable-car in the Engadin to the finest viewpoint in the area 
 * a typical Engadin menu with local specialities: e.g. capuns (cabbage rolls) or pizokel (noodles)
 * the fantastic sunset over the Upper Engadin, then the clear starry sky and the sea of lights that is St. Moritz

data.name: ISTA The Avalanche Training For You
data.abstract: Do you enjoy nature, mountains and skiing? Do you want more freedom, pleasure and safety? Do you care for yourself and for your friends?
data.description:
A NEW APPROACH

Despite the increasing number of backcountry recreationists, training opportunities, both in Switzerland and abroad, vary from country to country and mainly cater to advanced amateurs and professionals. ISTA’s training program is intended for the general public and is delivered by affiliated instructors and guides. The goal is not to provide extra equipment, but rather the knowledge and skills required to assess and prevent risk.
Inspired by the model of the Professional Association of Diving Instructors (PADI), ISTA offers a progressive international certification. Over 40 experts spanning 9 countries and 3 continents in the areas of education, sport psychology, transfer of knowledge, nutrition, meteorology, snow science, risk management and rescue methods, as well as mountain guides and ski instructors, were involved in the development of this unprecedented project in this fast-growing and increasingly exposed sector. Two modules are currently being covered - Discovery and ST1. The courses are supported by illustrated books featuring simple, clear, precise and playful descriptions, available in 4 languages (EN, FR, DE, IT).WHY?

Avalanches are not a fatality. Practitioners change, habits change – risks don’t. ISTA is the new essential approach to managing them.

ISTA is an international program that uses a standard universal language.

ISTA allows you to progress through various levels with a standardized method that is adapted to every skill level.

ISTA aims to foster knowledge sharing, exchange and the development of an international community.

All ISTA-certified participants benefit from the ISTA rewards program and its exclusive offers on travel, equipment and tourism services.DISCOVERY

[http://img.myswitzerland.com/669890]
The DISCOVERY course is a one-day introduction to the ISTA program. It is intended to introduce participants to the fundamentals of backcountry risk prevention and provide them with an overview of the range of skills to be developed. The main goal of the course is to inspire participants to continue learning.

After the course, participants will be able to:
 * follow the risk assessment process with the help of the course book
 * follow the crisis management process with the help of the avalanche rescue procedure

ST1

[http://img.myswitzerland.com/669891]
The ST1 course teaches basic avalanche risk prevention skills over two days. The goal of the course is for participants to acquire the basic skills and knowledge required to carry out the risk management process, implement rescue procedures and use rescue equipment.

After the course, with the help of the course book, participants will be able to:
 * Implement the risk assessment process
 * Identify favourable and unfavourable terrain
 * Understand rescue techniques
 * Use rescue gear
 * Implement the avalanche rescue procedure
 * Use the HFSA© system to assess mental, medical and energy-related risk factors

WHERE?

[http://img.myswitzerland.com/670065]
ISTA courses can be found in 28 Swiss resorts. Search for an instructor in your area here:

www.ista-education.com/en/where-find-us [http://www.ista-education.com/en/where-find-us]

data.name: Engadine Star
data.abstract: Enjoy the wonderful panorama from the comfort of your seat on this two-hour-train ride.
data.description:
Route: 
Landquart - Klosters - Zernez - St. Moritz

Start off in Landquart, climb the steep ascent to Klosters, pass through the Vereina tunnel, the world's longest meter-gauge tunnel, to Zernez and St. Moritz. Up here, activities are manifold: hike in the Swiss National Park, where you can view pristine flora and fauna up close, take a stroll around Lake St. Moritz, through the Staz Forest or climb up to the local mountain Corviglia or visit the local Segantini Museum, dedicated to the artist whose paintings capture the area so well. 

St. Moritz offers plenty to do and the Engadine Star gives you six hours of time in case you want to take the train back the same day.

From Zernez, you can alternatively take a Postbus over the Ofen Pass to the Val Müstair (Engadine-Meran Route Express) and on to Mals (Italy). Here, take the new Vinschgauer railway to Mediterranean Meran (www.sad.it; Swiss Travel System tickets are not valid).

data.name: Circling Trains in Brusio
data.abstract: When the Bernina Express was planned, the engineers who built it were faced with a difficult challenge.
data.description:
The train needed to bridge a considerable difference in altitude in a very short distance. The ride began in St. Moritz (1,775 m.a.s.l.), crossed the Bernina Pass (2,253 m.a.s.l.) and winds up in Tirano (429 m.a.s.l.). And since it was a train built specifically for tourists who wanted to see the lovely landscape, the train had to go through as few tunnels as possible. But the solution they came up with was quite ingenious: rather than use switchback tunnels, the train uses switchback viaducts that have have a diameter of 100 meters. Train passengers are usually in awe over this engineering feat.

How to get there:
Drive or take public transportation to St. Moritz, and from here take the Bernina Express.

data.name: Bernina Express
data.abstract: This panoramic train connects the north of Europe to its south – right through the UNESCO World Heritage site of Rhaetian Railway, passing by glaciers on its way down to palm trees.
data.description:
Crossing the Alps in the Bernina Express certainly is one of the most spectacular ways to do it. Along the way, the Bernina Express rolls over the 65-metre-high Landwasser Viaduct, the signature structure of the Rhaetian Railway and the UNESCO World Heritage site. Altogether the train passes through 55 tunnels and over 196 bridges on its way from Chur to Tirano. Travellers are treated to marvellous sights during their journey, like the Montebello curve with a view of the Bernina massif, the Morteratsch glacier, the three lakes Lej Pitschen, Lej Nair and Lago Bianco, the Alp Grüm and the Brusio Circular Viaduct. The journey can be extended aboard the Bernina Express Bus from Tirano to Lugano from February to November (daily in summer).

FACTS BERNINA EXPRESS (TRAIN)
Route: Chur/St. Moritz – Tirano (Italy) or vice versa Distance: 144 km Duration: 4 h - 4 h 30 min FACTS BERNINA EXPRESS BUS
Route: Tirano (Italy) – Lugano or vice versa Distance: 90 km Duration: 3 h EXCURSION TIPS
 * Arosa Railway – from Chur to Arosa within one hour. On just 26 km, the train negotiates an amazing 1000 m in altitude
 * Railway Museum Albula [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/experiences/albula-railway-museum/] – over 600 exhibits from more than 100 years of railway history, e.g. one of the last «Crocodile»-Locomotives
 * Landwasser World [https://shop.landwasserwelt.ch/en/] – unique experiences around the spectacular Landwasser Viaduct
 * Historical train Davos – Filisur [https://tickets.rhb.ch/en/pages/historical-trips]
 * The elegant mountain village of St. Moritz [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/destinations/st-moritz/]
 * Mountain excursion Diavolezza [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/diavolezza-1/]

FOOD & BEVERAGES
 * The Bernina Express minibar offers delicious snacks and refreshing beverages
 * The train does not feature a dining car. The guests spend their lunchtime in the Italian town of Tirano

TIMETABLE
 * Summer and winter timetable panoramic trains [https://tickets.rhb.ch/en/pages/bernina-express]
 * Timetable regular scheduled service [http://www.sbb.ch/en/home.html]

TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book public transport tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

RESERVATION
Apart from a valid ticket, a seat reservation is required on both train and bus. Surcharge applies depending on route and season.

Reserve here [https://tickets.rhb.ch/en/pages/bernina-express]BROCHURE
Fascinating and comprehensive information around the Bernina Express, featuring highlights and relevant facts and figures, can be downloaded here:
PDF brochure [https://issuu.com/stnet/docs/sw20091.1006.2001.3064?fr=xKAE9_zMzMw]

data.name: Adventure rides aboard the Rhaetian Railway / Bernina Express
data.abstract: The city of Chur and the Rhaetian Railway simply go hand in hand. The RhB provides public rail transport from Chur for the SBB and its red trains take you along stunning routes to your destination.
data.description:
Chur is the starting point for the famous adventure rides aboard the Bernina and Glacier Express. Every inch of this rail network is one big treat, no matter whether you are on the Alpine crossing from glacier ice to Gelato al Limone or on the route from St. Moritz to Zermatt over 291 bridges and through 91 tunnels, or whether you are taking a day trip or a multi-day trip, or whether you are riding on an express or a regular train.

The Rhaetian Railway also regularly schedules trips aboard special trains. These may include a steam train ride or a culinary expedition.

data.name: Lej Nair and Lej dals Chöds
data.abstract: In the Canton of Graubünden, flat moors cover about 3,000 hectares of land. And in these flat moorlands around 10% of Graubünden's flora and fauna can be found. Therefore, these must be protected to the largest extent possible.
data.description:
In order to protect this sensitive fauna and flora, the community and spa resort administration set up an ecologically important project: The damaged trails at the Lej Nair and Lej dals Chöds (Hahnensee) Lakes were diverted. In addition, information panels were erected, which draw attention to the moorlands at risk. These panels also point out rules of conduct in these protected areas and inform the guest about the uniqueness and importance of these moorlands. From Lej dals Chöds one can hike on a fantastically beautiful trail to Champfèr or to St.Moritz-Bad. 




INFORMATION
Hiking time:
Silvaplana-Surlej - Lej Nair: 30 minutes
Lej Nair - Lej dals Chöds: one hour
Lej dals Chöds - Silvaplana-Surlej: one hour

difference in altitude 50 - 350 meters

data.name: The potholes of Maloja
data.abstract: Near Maloja, there is a group of 36 potholes, some smaller, some larger, and from the tower of Castello Belvedere the views of the Bergell valley and the lake region of the Upper Engadine are breathtaking.
data.description:
After the last ice age, about 1000 years ago, the glaciers receded from the lowlands, setting large quantities of meltwater, ice, rocks and sand free. Normally, this creates polished rock surfaces and striations, or potholes on occasion, as in this case. Meltwater will always find a way through the crevasses and the water along with the sand it carried hit the rocky bottom with tremendous pressure. The constant grinding in the same place resulted in potholes of different depth, depending on the length of time and the hardness of the rock. Many potholes are filled with water because it has no outlet to flow out of the rock. Some have been covered with sand and rock since the glacier receded and continue to be hidden.

Hikers must stay on the trail and dogs should be leashed at all times. The best time to visit is between spring and autumn. 

Directions
Take the Rhaetian Railway to St. Moritz and from there the postbus to the post office in Maloja.

There is also a circular path for walkers. It is about 2.5 km long, takes approximately 1 hour and is easy to do. It starts at the post office in Maloja heading in the direction of Castello Belvedere and continues to Marmitte gigange and Sette marmite, to the high moor, through the pine forest and back to the post office of Maloja.

data.name: Julier Pass Route
data.description:
The Julier Pass Route leads from Chur through deep Alpine valleys, over the Julier Pass and on to St. Moritz. Discover the attraction of Switzerland’s oldest town, Chur –before moving on via Churwalden to Valbella and more spectacular sights, along with sweeping views over the Lenzerheide. The Seilpark on the Alp Pradaschier, with the world’s longest sled run, is of course yet another spectacular sight. (PostBus stop Churwalden, Post: Sesselbahn Pradaschier). 

Lenzerheide, too, offers active year-round fun; with the idyllic Heidsee lake that invites visitors to take a refreshing summer plunge; and Globi hiking trail that appeals to children and those young at heart! (PostBus stop Lenzerheide Post). The Lenz sun-terrace offers delightful views over the Albulatal valley and, from this point, the Parc Ela nature reserve extends all the way to Bivio. 

One of many recommended proposals, is a hike from Savognin (PostBus stop Savognin Posta) over the Alp Flix to one of the numerous PostBus stops that lie along this stretch i.e. PostBus stops Rona; Sur –and in summer there’s also an Alpin Bus connection with Alp Flix, leading to Marmorera, Dorf; Bivio, Posta. Bivio is door to the Julier Pass, where the European Rhein-Donau watershed flows, and location of the mountain-bike route over the Septimer Pass (PostBus stop Bivio, Posta). Following Silvaplana, with its unique lake-studded plateau, you find yourself in St. Moritz and the realm of excellent hotels and exclusive shopping possibilities….and that’s not all! Here visitors also delight in the spectacle of horse racing on the region’s deep frozen lake, along with the regal polo snow sport, and the world’s one and only natural bob ice-run that all in all make the beautiful resort a Mecca for winter sport enthusiasts. 
Additional useful information on the PostBus excursion routes and a wealth of pictures and video clips can be found at the link in the right-hand box.

data.name: Rhaetian Railways Landwasser Viaduct
data.abstract: A must for all railway fans – beauty and boldness combined. With its 65m high pillars, tapering towards the top, the viaduct is one of the most elegant bridge constructions in Graubünden. The most frequently photographed feature of the Rhaetian Railways.
data.description:
Between Thusis and St. Moritz the Landwasser viaduct is the most spectacular construction on the 63 kilometers long Albula stretch. And the Albula and Bernina routes of the scenic Rhaetian railway form part of the UNESCO World Heritage list since mid July 2008 – as first of three railway lines worldwide.

The construction of the main pillars of the Landwasser viaduct in 1901/1902 was considered a huge architectural feat, as this took place without scaffolding and solely two cranes. And 106 years later, in the year 2009, the masonry and track trough of the viaduct were repaired for the very fist time. The viaduct wall of natural dolomite lime is 142 meters long and at 65 meters high extends in a curve over the rugged Landwasser Valley and inside a tunnel, the entrance of which is on a vertical rock wall.

From the Filisur village you reach a beautiful vantage point in just half an hour on foot, from where you have amazing views of the viaduct. Next a path leads either down to the river, under the viaduct and into a ravine, or at the fork to the lookout point in around 2 hours and on to the Wiesner viaduct. This viaduct you can cross on a footpath while enjoying incredible in-depth views down under.

data.name: Fatbiking
data.abstract: Biking is no longer only possible during the warm seasons. Winter has been taken over by the new trend «fatbiking», which offers great training opportunities for active people as well as leisurely rides for pleasure seekers. The over-sized tires make riding on snow a safe and fun adventure.
data.description:
Fatbikes, or snowbikes, were developed in North America around 10 years ago. They were constructed to glide over the snow without sinking in. Fatbikes have massive tires and are ridden with very little pressure. They are ideal for difficult terrain such as snow, sand, sludge, and mud. After having become very popular in the snow and sand deserts of the USA, especially in Alaska and New Mexico, these bikes are at the moment conquering Switzerland as well. 

Here's a list of destinations which offer fatbiking:

data.name: Albula Adventure Train – Let’s go to the Railway Paradise
data.abstract: Every Sunday you can take the fairytale railway trip from Landquart to Samedan through the UNESCO World Heritage Site in a panorama or classic wooden train carriage.
data.description: The Landquart-Chur-Thusis-Filisur-Bergün-St. Moritz line is where the magic happens. On the open-top RhB wagon, you can almost reach out and touch the sky. You'll feel like you're on a rollercoaster or a ghost train as you pass through the dizzying loop tunnels, but on the viaducts it's more like being in a cable car. Plenty of fresh air and variety are guaranteed. Visitors who prefer a more nostalgic experience shouldn't miss a ride in the open wooden panorama cars. The classic “Crocodile” locomotive carries families and railway fans to the Albula Valley. Open-top panorama carriages or traditional wooden carriages take visitors through the mountainous Domleschg valley over the famous Solis and Landwasser viaducts or through the loop tunnels between Bergün and Preda.

data.name: Orienteering on Corviglia
data.abstract: Anyone who loves orienteering listen up: between July and August, control points of an orienteering course are permanently marked in the Upper Engadin for optimum altitude training amidst the impressive high-Alpine mountain and lake landscape.
data.description:
Between 1 July and 31 August, 15 orienteering control points are set up on both Corviglia above St. Moritz and Muottas Muragl. They are standard orienteering control points, without the need for fixed installation or time measurement. All training areas are at more than 2,000 metres above sea level and therefore perfect for altitude training.

In each case, the route begins right by the upper station. The orienteering map can be purchased at the valley station for CHF 5.00. Groups should please book sufficiently in advance.

data.name: Hahnensee Descent
data.abstract: The Hahnensee ski piste in the Corvatsch-Furtschellas ski region is regarded as one of the Engadin’s most beautiful downhill runs. It is noted for its peaceful setting and stunning panorama as well as for the high demands it will place on your skiing skills.
data.description:
The 3,300 m high Corvatsch is one of Switzerland’s highest skiing mountains. Its snow-sure northern slopes are home to an exciting network of varied pistes of all degrees of difficulty. Most prestigious of all is the almost 9 km route on the highly demanding Hahnensee piste. Starting at the top station for the Giand'Alva chairlift it ends up in the valley below in St. Moritz Bad. Insiders consider the Bergrestaurant Hahnensee with its wonderful views to be an indispensable stopover.
Starting point: Giand Alva (2643 m a.s.l.) 

Accessibility of starting point: chairlift 

Destination: St.Moritz Bad (1772 m a.s.l.) 

Length: 9 km 

Altitude difference: 871 Meter 

Level of difficulty: very difficult (normal slope) 

Food and beverages: at the start and on the way

data.name: The challenge of Telemark
data.abstract: Is it time to learn a new skill on skis? Try telemark – skiing at its most original and unfiltered, with elegant, dynamic turns and hairpin bends.
data.description: “Free your heel and your mind will follow.” The telemark approach, where the heel is not fixed like with conventional alpine skis, offers an exhilarating ride across the slopes. Telemark is skiing at its most original and unfiltered. Anyone who can master the precarious turns deserves respect. For two hours, a ski instructor from the Swiss Ski School St. Moritz gives guests tips and tricks to improve their telemark skiing. This graceful sport is not as simple as it looks, but it’s not impossible to learn either. Participants must have already mastered parallel turns on red runs. The package includes rental equipment for beginners or advanced skiers plus private lessons with a professional instructor and is guaranteed to evoke feelings of exhilaration and euphoria. Telemark is extremely liberating!

data.name: Piz Nair
data.abstract: A stately ibex, head bowed, sits atop its throne on the summit of Piz Nair, overlooking the Upper Engadin at its feet.
data.description:
The Chantarella-Corviglia funicular railway takes you from the centre of St. Moritz up to the top of the resort’s local mountain. The Signal cable car from St. Moritz Bad also takes you in the direction of Corviglia. Another cable car then takes summiteers even closer to heaven and the Piz Nair upper station at exactly 3,056 metres above sea level. Without breaking a sweat or exerting yourself, you can enjoy an unforgettable view of St. Moritz, the Upper Engadin lake region and the mountains.

The summit falls away steeply on all sides, but with a sturdy pair of boots you can tackle the descent via the picturesque Lej Suvretta or into Valetta Schlattain. Mountain bikers love the descent of Alp Suvretta back to St. Moritz, with an altitude difference of 1,200 metres.

The “Clean Energy Tour [http://www.clean-energy.ch/fileadmin/user_upload_cleanenergy/user_upload/pdf/Clean_Energy_Tour_Flyer.pdf]” between Piz Nair and St. Moritz provides an extensive presentation of the “Energy from Water, Sun, Wind and Biomass” project.

Altitude: 3,022 metres 
How to get there: Train from Chur to St. Moritz, funicular railways to Chantarella/Corviglia, cable car to Piz Nair 
Views: Towards Muottas Muragl, the Piz Palü and Bernina region, Corvatsch, the Bregaglia Alps, Italy’s Monte Disgrazia in the distance; to the west and north lie Piz Julier, Piz Ela and Piz Kesch 
Attractions: View from the second-highest mountain in the Upper Engadin accessible by cable car; long bike descents 
Food and drink: Panorama restaurant on Piz Nair, restaurants in Corviglia and Lej da la Pêsch 
Accommodation: None on the summit 
Groups: In the panorama restaurant by arrangement 
Winter: Winter sports area of St. Moritz / Upper Engadin 
Special comments: The 60-year-old bronze ibex, “Guardiaun Grischun” is the symbol of Piz Nair.

data.name: Diavolezza - Isola Pers – Morteratsch glacier
data.abstract: Like gigantic tongues, the Pers Glacier and the Morteratsch Glacier are pushing from the snow-covered peaks of Piz Palü and Piz Bernina in the direction of Pontresina.
data.description:
This is a classic glacier traverse in an impressive world of glaciers and should only be done in the company of a mountain guide. The tour starts at the mountain station of the Diavolezza cable car at 2973 m. Across the glacier, past the rocky knoll of the lost island "Isla Persa" and the wide arm of the Morteratsch Glacier, you reach a side moraine and finally the Boval Hut. Piz Bernina (4049 m) and Piz Palü, covered by glaciers, create a spectacular backdrop. Along the side moraine, the trail continues to the mouth of the glacier and leads through its forefield to the Morteratsch train station. 

Traversing the glacier is recommended only with a mountain guide. Children over the age of 8 are welcome. Good equipment is required, preferably mountain or hiking books with profiled rubber soles. Physical fitness and surefootedness are necessary for this tour. The hiking time is approximately 5 hours. This tour is not suitable for dogs. 

How to get there:
Drive or take public transportation from St. Moritz/ Pontresina to Bernina-Diavolezza, to Diavolezza by aerial cable-car. 

Diavolezza viewing platform 
Situated directly above the Pers Glacier, its form matching that of the glacier moraine, the platform perfectly fits the scenery. In addition to the spectacular views, the visitors might also hear the story of how the Morteratsch Glacier was named – the legend of the beautiful she-devil. The traverse of the Morteratsch Glacier and the Diavolezza viewing platform are both part of the UNESCO world natural heritage and therefore offer something for either target group. Also, the Bernina Glacier app provides an exciting experience in the fantastic scenery.
For additional information about the guided Diavolezza-Morteratsch glacier tour of the Pontresina mountaineering school click here

data.name: Palm Express
data.abstract: From the impressive glaciers of Engadin to the lovely palm trees of Lugano: The Palm Express invites visitors to a pleasantly diverse four-hour PostBus journey.
data.description:
After leading over the Maloja pass, the road winds down to the Val Bregaglia. At Astasegna, travellers cross the Swiss-Italian border and little later arrive at the charming Italian town of Chiavenna. The journey’s final destination is Lugano, city of Mediterranean flair and one of Ticino’s main urban areas.
FACTS
Route: St. Moritz – Menaggio – Lugano
Distance: 130 km
Duration: approx. 3.5 h

Important: Passport or identity card required for border crossing to Italy.

FOOD & BEVERAGES
No catering services on the PostBus.TIMETABLE
All connections here [https://postauto.ch/en/leisure/palm-express].TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]
RESERVATIONS
Seat reservation required, without surcharge:reservation here [https://postauto.ch/en/leisure/palm-express].

data.name: Muottas Muragl
data.abstract: With his keen eye for beautiful landscapes, and unique light conditions, Segantini discovered this special patch of the earth. Between the wide valley of the River Inn and the valley that leads to the Bernina Pass, this is probably the most beautiful vantage point above the lakes of Upper Engadine. Sunsets from here are a sight to behold.
data.description:
Between 1905 and 1907, the first funicular railway in Engadine was built here by Von Roll. Although modernised on many occasions, it has essentially remained the same to this day – just like the view of the Upper Engadine lakeland including St. Moritz, the Piz Palü and the Piz Bernina with its white Biancograt ridge. 

Here you can hike into panoramic views in the literal sense: over to Alp Languard (Pontresina) or up to the Segantini hut and the Schafberg, where the artist Giovanni Segantini died a lonely death. Especially enjoyable are the panoramic views from the large sun terrace of the romantic mountain hotel - and sunsets as seen from here are truly remarkable. The train runs until late at night - but you can also take a room at the attractive hotel. 

A funicular railway takes over the 700-meter climb from Punt Muragl up to the Muottas Muragl for all scenic lovers – accompanied in the upper section by sun collectors that cover the energy requirements of the mountain dwelling in an environmentally friendly way. In winter, Muottas Muragl is now a playground for sledgers, snowshoe hikers and connoisseurs. In winter, Muottas Muragl is now a playground for sledgers, snowshoe hikers and connoisseurs.

Altitude: 2454m 
Accessibility: 
Punt Muragl station of the RhB railway, in the Samedan / Pontresina / St. Moritz triangle; funicular railway (10 minutes) to Muottas Muragl 
View: Lakelands of upper Engadine, St. Moritz; Piz Palü, Piz Bernina with Biancograt 
Attractions: Hikes to the Segantini hut and Schafberg; climate path 
Culinary aspects: Hotel Romantik: stylish pine and walnut ambiance, aperitifs, lunches and festive candle-light dinners 
Overnight stays: First energy-plus hotel in the Alps: 16 romantic rooms with WC, shower and/or bath as well as costfree Wi-Fi 
Groups: Panorama Restaurant 160, pinewood lounge 24, glass-fronted Restaurant Scatla 50, sun terrace 100 seating places; Villa Lyss, renovated Maiensäss and romantic huts for 15 to 25 people 
Winter: Toboggan-run to the valley station, well prepared philosophy trail, snowshoe hiking path but no skiing operations
Special comments: "Sine sole sileo" – the world’s most precise sundial

data.name: Skiing in the light of the full moon
data.abstract: A mountain, a cable car, a mountain restaurant and free use of a slope in the mystical moonlight: this is the fabulous experience of skiing in the light of the full moon on the Diavolezza.
data.description: Glüna Plaina is the Romansh word for the full moon. Friday is always a special day for keen skiers and snowboarders in the Engadin as they head to Diavolezza. When the full moon starts to glow, the mountain railway beckons night skiers. The slopes are freshly prepared and lit only by the moonlight. The joyous mood is infectious. A dream opportunity for anyone fascinated by the moon or those who didn’t get their fill of the slopes during the day. The cable cars run from 7:30 p.m. to 11 p.m. To replenish your strength, why not meet at the summit to dine in the mountain restaurant. Some people take a moment on the terrace before or after the meal to simply enjoy the panoramic views: the Piz Palü, the Bernina range, the glacier – in the moonlight, it all looks simply “fabulus”, which means “fairytale” in Romansch.

data.name: Practice yoga on the slopes
data.abstract: The journey is the reward: set against the stunning backdrop of the Engadin mountains, “Yoga on Snow” keeps guests moving and encourages a deeper understanding of the body.
data.description:
"The “Yoga on Snow” course takes place on the Corviglia Paradiso slope. The guests practice yoga while also perfecting their skiing technique. Accompanied by host and instructor Sabrina Nussbaum from Suvretta Snowsports School, they complete two runs, each with four stop-off points. These points are marked by wooden signs. Each time the guests reach one of the signs, they take a break and discuss a specific yoga topic. The guests learn new ways to exercise in the mountains. They have lots of fun and, of course, improve their skiing skills along the way.

"

performer.name: Sabrina Nussbaum von Suvretta Snowsports School

data.name: Yoga Piste
data.abstract: A world-first with the Paradiso piste on the Corviglia home to a brand-new Yoga piste. Focus is on slowing down and experiencing descents at a different pace. An opportunity to consciously practice skiing thanks to the new Yoga on Snow Project.
data.description: "Yoga on Snow" is a new and unique way to relax and leads one to the slopes in diverse locations, providing an opportunity to newly learn skiing in the sense of a more relaxed way. Enhance your perception skills as you admire beautiful natural landscapes; enjoy sensual wellbeing, and a state of relaxation far from everyday reality to newly awaken life’s energy. Four fixed spots have been set-up here; on which you can practice Yoga on Snow either independently or under expert guidance.

data.name: The World’s first Yoga Piste
data.abstract: Yoga fans can now experience the Indian teachings directly on the piste: In four “quiet zones”, Yoga on Snow can be practiced independently or under expert guidance of the Suvretta Snowsports School.
data.description:
The four locations deal with various Yoga themes. For example: “OM – Arrival“, “PRANA – life energy and breath“, “VINYASA – connecting movement and breathing”, and “ASANAS – stability, strength and balance“. 

Yoga on Snow lessons can be booked individually or as a group at the Suvretta Snowsports School.

data.name: Patagonia/Black Diamond Alpine Safety Center
data.abstract: Complete Avalanche Security Training Center.
data.description:
According to the slogan: "Free Ride & Free Ski? - Yes, but safely!", free riders and free skiers may practice the use of GPS and sounding poles, thus increasing and refreshing their know-how on issues related to avalanches. 

The small brochure "avalanche threat, life threat" is available at different locations and contains much information on the subject. It is also a useful document to take along on a ski tour.

With 2,500 different kinds of whisky, this is the largest selection in the world. Several times, Devil's Place has received an entry in the "Guinness Book of World Records" for its outstanding whisky collection.

data.name: Muottas Muragl: plus-energy hotel (2,456 m)
data.abstract: During summer 2010, the entire Berghotel Muottas Muragl was completely renovated. Particular focus was placed on the aspect of environmental-friendliness, giving rise to the first plus-energy hotel in the Alps. On request the hotel offers free guided tours for groups of at least five persons with a special focus on the new energy concept.
data.description:
Besides constructing the building according to the principles and requirements of the Swiss ""Minergie"" ecological label, this project went one step further. The surface area of the building was extended from 1,700 sq. metres to 2,700 sq. metres.
Hot water is obtained by means of solar energy produced by the 56 sq. metres of pipe solar collectors installed in the glass window panes in the basement. Sixteen thermal loops with an average length of 200 metres, making 3,200 metres in total, supply the entire building with geothermal energy. In addition, all the necessary electricity is generated by the most efficient photovoltaic system in Switzerland, extending 228 metres along the railway line. Any excess of solar energy is stored in the ground via the thermal loops, thus regenerating the geothermal mass. The recovery of the waste heat from the cooling units, exhaust air and the machine room are further measures to transform the new building into a sustainable and environmentally-friendly enterprise that, taken over the entire year, even produces more energy than it actually needs.

data.name: Tobogganing on Muottas Muragl
data.abstract: 20 curves and rapid straights take you through pine and larch forests down this 4.2 km long toboggan run. An amazingly varied and exciting run is guaranteed for both young and old alike.
data.description:
It is an easy ride by funicular railway to the starting point for this toboggan run. First admire the panoramic views of the Upper Engadin with the Engadin lakes and the Bernina mountain range and enjoy refreshments at the mountain hotel before making your rapid descent to Punt Muragl. 
Starting point: Muottas Muragl (2,456 m.a.s.l.)
Accessibility of starting point: Funicular railway 
Finishing point: Punt Muragl (1,738 m.a.s.l.)
Altitude difference: 718 metres
Length: 4.2 kilometres
Level of difficulty: Medium
Toboggan hire onsite: Yes
Illuminated for night sledging: No
Option to eat: At the start

data.name: Culinary delight with an enchanting view
data.abstract: They say it is the most beautiful in the world: the view from Muottas Muragl across the Engadin is so unique that it has been inspiring poets, philosophers and artists since time immemorial. It is even topped when accompanied by a delicious dinner.
data.description:
The panoramic restaurant at Romantik Hotel Muottas Muragl is situated at 2,456 metres above sea level and offers an unbelievable view of the Engadin. Those who can resist anything but temptation are first thoroughly intoxicated by the spectacular sunset and then indulge in “mountain dining” as they have never indulged before.

Guests who eat a gluten-free, lactose-free, vegan or vegetarian diet need not miss out on this boundless pleasure – all dishes are specifically labelled.


 * Reservations recommended
 * Last cable car to the valley: 11 p.m.

data.name: Mama mal 3 in Pontresina
data.abstract: Panoramic views as far as the eye can see. Blogger family Mama mal 3 (mum with three kids) enjoyed nature at its most impressive in Pontresina and felt right at home from the word go.
data.description:
Mama mal 3 tested Pontresina as a family destination from 21 to 23 June 2019. They stayed at the Grand Hotel Kronenhof [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodations/grand-hotel-kronenhof/]. 



They’re going to tell you in their own words all about what they discovered and experienced in Pontresina: 

“We really enjoyed our short break in Pontresina. We were totally blown away by the fantastic panoramic views that we could ride up to in the comfort of cable cars and chair lifts. There was an enormous variety of things to see: deep snow on Diavolezza, views of lakes and green meadows on Muottas Muragl. Then there was the rocky, boulder-strewn path to the Morteratsch Glacier. The natural features on show in this region are truly phenomenal. Even with kids in tow, everything is very manageable. There is always something to do and every restaurant we visited made the children welcome.” 

You can read their entire blog about the trip here [https://mamamal3.ch/2019/06/pontresina/].



Pontresina has countless other great experiences in store for the whole family. A particular highlight is the hike into Val Roseg with Fix the Fox [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/fix-shows-you-his-world/]. Fix follows the family every step of the way and introduces them to the secrets of the forest.
